ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: A heavily quantitative intermediate economics course masked as an introductory course. Be prepared to read the textbook completely through and study the graphs a lot on your own. If you've taken AP before, you'll be fine. If you want an easier curve and less math, take the lecture version.
Basic Micro--nothing special. Foundation of modern economics, I guess. Worth taking, though Steven Barry's not bad either.
The material is not very well taught, and is especially confusing for students with no background in economics.
The class has a decent workload, make sure you take Tolga and not Katerina.

The course is recommended to an Economics major only; not to a person seeking to explore a field for fun, not to a person who might major in Economics/EPE and lastly not to a person who's seeking to complete a QR requirement.
I would recommend microecon to somebody who has no previous knowledge of the disciple and wants to get a feel of the subject.

You learn significantly more than the lecture course, which makes it worthwhile in retrospect, but it may not have been worth during the semester. A lot of kids far worse at econ got much higher grades in the lecture, and I don't know yet whether or not the additional knowledge offsets that.

Thisclass is exactly what it says on the tin, but honestly looking back, I can't figure out what I got out of this class that I wouldn't have gotten out of the lecture. The sections were basically lecture-format anyway and Professor Simons didn't seem to like answering our questions very much. The homework is a little tedious and a little long but manageable and the tests stick pretty close to the material assuming a decent amount of studying. I might have had a little bit of a sticky experience because most of the vocal people in the class tended to be libertarians and it was a little off-putting, but I guess that's par for the course in intro econ regardless.

Difficulty of the midterms aren't that hard. but the final sneaks up on you b/c of all the material crunched together. Teachers are alright- and often quite humorous- but a serious problem is that they tend to either over-complicate or confuse things when teaching. (this cost me quite a bit on the second mid-term)
I would say its a good way to learn micro if you like micro and need it for the econ major requirement. Its probably harder than the lecture but not too unmanagable
